posts._title: Andy Milligan – Guru, the Mad Monk (1970)
posts.title: Guru, the Mad Monk
posts.excerpt: A deranged 15th Century prison colony chaplain exploits his power to get money for his church including murder and grave robbing committed by his vampire mistress and one-eyed hunchback assistant.

posts.title: Équateur
posts.excerpt: Gainsbourg’s second film. Booed when screened out of competition in Cannes 1983, the film was a commercial and critical failure. posts._title: Werner Herzog – Tod für fünf Stimmen AKA Gesualdo: Death for Five Voices (1995)
posts.title: Tod für fünf Stimmen
posts.excerpt: Quote:Gesualdo was a nutcase, but a brilliant one. His madrigals are among the most moving moments in music history. You will walk away from this film realizing all of the above. posts.title: Noordzee, Texas

posts._title: Grzegorz Królikiewicz – Na wylot AKA Through and Through (1973)
posts.title: Na wylot
posts.excerpt: Quote:“Through and Through” is a legendary feature focusing on radicalization of cinematic language. The film transgresses traditional methods of narrative construction, which is characteristic of its genre. This non-conentional treatment of the cinematic form places this film somewhere between experimental art and cinema, in a domain that does not properly belong to either field. Krolikiewicz’s …

posts._title: Mohamed Malas – Ahlam el Madina AKA Dreams of the City (1984)
posts.title: Ahlam el Madina
posts.excerpt: “Mother, come and see how beautiful Damascus is!”, little Omar cries out to his mother, a young woman drained by mourning. The widely acclaimed, partially autobiographical, Dreams of the City marks the turn towards auteur Syrian cinema, resurrecting the memories of childhood of the working poor. A young widow and her two sons are forced …
